   CROSS REFERENCES
   Sex offenses - see Crimes Code §§ 3101 et seq.
   Open lewdness - see Crimes Code § 5901
   Prostitution and related offenses - see Crimes Code § 5902
   Obscene and other sexual materials - see Crimes Code § 5903
   Sex related offenses - see GEN. OFF.
Ch. 678
806.01   FINDINGS; PURPOSE.
   (a)   The location of adult entertainment establishments is of vital concern
to the Borough Council of the Borough of Ellwood City when the location is in
or near areas where minors may learn, play, pass by or would be exposed to the
advertising, window displays or general atmosphere accompanying the operation.
Thus, it is a firm belief of the legislative body that it has a vital duty and
role to protect the moral fiber and standards of Borough residents, in
particular the minors of the community.
   (b)   Council members, in enacting these regulations relative to adult
entertainment establishments, exercise the power which has been granted to
them. The Borough Council does not attempt or intend to absolutely prohibit
adult entertainment establishments in the Borough, but rather seeks to regulate
matters to promote, protect and facilitate the public health, safety, morals
and general welfare of all of the residents of the Borough of Ellwood City.
(Ord. 2235. Passed 8-10-98.)
806.02   DEFINITIONS.
   (a)   It is the purpose of this section to provide clear and concise
definitions of those words, terms and phrases most commonly utilized in the
provisions of these regulations in order to assist with any interpretation of
said provisions and to insure uniformity of application. It is intended that
the following words, term and phrases, whenever used, shall be construed as
defined in this section, unless from the context a different meaning is clearly
intended.
   (b)   For the purpose of this chapter, “adult entertainment establishments”
are defined as follows:
      (1)   Adult bookstore. Any establishment having a substantial or
significant portion (twenty-five percent or greater) of its stock in:
         A.   Books, films, magazines or other periodicals or other forms of
audio or visual representation which are distinguished or characterized by an
emphasis on depiction or description of specified sexual activities or
specified anatomical areas;
         B.   Instruments, devices or paraphernalia which are designed for use
in connection with specified sexual activities.
       (2)   Adult cabaret.
         A.   An establishment devoted to adult entertainment, either with or
without a liquor license, presenting material distinguished or characterized by
an emphasis on matter depicting, describing, or relating to sexual activities
or anatomical genital areas;
         B.   A cabaret that features topless dancers, go-go dancers,
strippers, male or female impersonators, or similar entertainers for
observation by patrons.
      (3)   Adult mini-motion picture theater. An enclosed or unenclosed
building with a capacity of more than five, but less that fifty, persons used
for presenting any form of audio or visual material, and in which a substantial
portion of the total presentation time measured on an annual basis is devoted
to the showing of material which is distinguished or characterized by an
emphasis on depiction or description of specified sexual activities or
specified anatomical areas.
      (4)   Adult motel. A motel or similar establishment, offering public
accommodations for any consideration, which provides patrons with material
distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on depiction or descriptions of
specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas.
       (5)   Adult motel studio. A motel or similar establishment offering
public accommodations for any consideration, which provides patrons with
material distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on depiction or
descriptions of specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas.
      (6)   Adult motion picture arcade. An enclosed or unenclosed building
with a capacity of fifty or more persons used for presenting any form of audio
or visual material, and in which a substantial portion of the total
presentation time measured on an annual basis is devoted to the showing of
material which is distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on depiction or
description of specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas.
      (7)   Adult motion picture theater. An enclosed or unenclosed building
with a capacity of fifty or more persons used for presenting any form of audio
or visual material, and in which a substantial portion of the total
presentation time measured on an annual basis is devoted to the showing of
material which is distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on depiction or
description of specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas.
      (8)   Adult newsrack. Any coin-operated machine or device which dispenses
material substantially devoted to the depiction of specified sexual activities
or specified anatomical areas.
      (9)   Adult theater. A theater, concert hall, auditorium or other similar
establishment, either indoor or outdoor in nature, which regularly features
live performances which are distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on
specified sexual activities or by exposure of specified anatomical areas for
observation by patrons.
       (10)   Bath house. An establishment or business which provides the
services of baths of all kinds, including all forms and methods of hydrotherapy
during which specified anatomical areas are displayed or specified sexual
activity occurs. This section shall not apply to hydrotherapy treatment
practiced by, or under the supervision of, a medical practitioner. A medical
practitioner, for the purpose of this definition, shall be a medical doctor,
physician, chiropractor or similar professional licensed by the Commonwealth of
Pennsylvania.
      (11)   Body painting studio. Any establishment or business which provides
the service of applying paint or other substance, whether transparent or
nontransparent, to or on the human body when specified anatomical areas are
exposed.
      (12)   Massage parlor. Any establishment or business which provides the
services of massage and body manipulation, including exercises, heat and light
treatments of the body, and all forms and methods of physiotherapy, unless
operated by a medical practitioner, chiropractor or professional physical
therapist licensed by the Commonwealth. This definition does not include an
athletic club, health club, school, gymnasium, reducing salon, spa or similar
establishment, where massage or similar manipulation of the human body is
offered as an incidental or accessory service.
      (13)   Out call service activity. An establishment or business which
operates an out call service which consists of individuals leaving the premises
upon request or by appointment to visit other premises for a period of time for
the purpose of providing any service, during which time specified anatomical
areas are displayed or specified sexual activity occurs.
      (14)   Sexual encounter center. Any business, agency or person who or
which, for any form of consideration or gratuity, provides a place where two or
more persons, not all members of the same family, may congregate, assemble, or
associate for the purpose of engaging in specified sexual activity or exposing
specified anatomical areas, excluding psychosexual workshops operated by a
medical practitioner, as defined in paragraph (b)(10) hereof, licensed by the
Commonwealth to engage in sexual therapy.
       (15)   Miscellaneous businesses or establishments. Any other business or
establishment which offers its patrons services or entertainment characterized
by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to specified sexual
activities or specified anatomical areas.
   (c)   “Specified anatomical areas”, as used herein, shall mean and include
any of the following:
       (1)   Less than completely and opaquely covered human genitals, pubic
region, buttocks, anus or female breasts below a point immediately above the
top of the areola; or
      (2)   Human male genitals in a discernibly turgid state, even if
completely and opaquely covered.
   (d)   “Specified sexual activities” includes the following:
      (1)   Showing of human genitals in a state of sexual stimulation or
arousal;
      (2)   Acts of masturbation, sexual intercourse, sodomy, bestiality,
necrophilia, sadomasochistic abuse, fellatio, cunnilingus, or any other
specified sexual activity prohibited by law;
      (3)   Fondling or erotic touching of human genitals, pubic region,
buttock or female breasts.
(Ord. 2235. Passed 8-10-98.)
806.03   LOCATION REQUIREMENTS; PARKING.
   (a)   No adult entertainment establishment shall be located within 1,000
feet of any other adult entertainment establishment.
   (b)   No adult entertainment establishment shall be located within specified
distances of certain land uses as set forth below:
      (1)   No such establishment shall be located within 1,000 feet of a
dwelling.
      (2)   No such establishment shall be located within 1,000 feet of any
parcel of land which contains any one or more of the following specified land
uses:
         A.   Amusement park;
         B.   Camp (for minors' activities);
         C.   Child care facility;
         D.   Church;
         E.   Community center;
         F.   Museum;
         G.   Park;
         H.   Playground;
         I.   School and school bus stops;
         J.   Other lands where minors congregate; or
         K.   Library.
   (c)   The distance between any two adult entertainment establishments shall
be measured in a straight line, without regard to intervening structures, from
the closest point on the exterior parcel line of each establishment, and the
distance between an adult entertainment establishment any land use specified in
subsection (b) hereof, shall be measured in a straight line, without regard to
intervening structures, from the closest point on the exterior parcel line of
the adult entertainment establishment to the closest point on the property line
of said land use.
   (d)   The establishment shall provide off-street parking spaces for each two
seats. All other off-street parking requirements shall be as required by the
Zoning Code in effect.
(Ord. 2235. Passed 8-10-98.)
806.04   VISIBILITY FROM THE STREET.
   No person operating an adult entertainment establishment shall permit, or
cause to be permitted, any stock in trade which depicts, describes or relates
to specified sexual activities and/or specified anatomical areas as defined
herein, to be viewed from the street, sidewalk, or highway.
(Ord. 2235. Passed 8-10-98.)
806.05   SIGNS; WINDOW DISPLAYS.
   (a)   All signs shall be flat signs.
   (b)   The gross surface area of a wall-mounted sign shall not exceed fifty
square feet.
   (c)   No merchandise or pictures of the products or entertainment on the
premises shall be displayed in the window area or any area where they can be
viewed from the sidewalk in front of the building.
   (d)   Window areas shall not be covered or made opaque in any way. No signs
shall be placed in any window. A one and one-half square foot sign may be
placed on the door to state hours of operation and admittance to adults only.
(Ord. 2235. Passed 8-10-98.)
806.06   PERMIT REQUIRED.
   (a)   An application for a permit shall be made on a form provided by the
Zoning Office. The applicant shall provide truthful, accurate, full and
complete information as requested in conjunction with the issuance of a permit.
   (b)   The Zoning Office shall issue a permit to an applicant within ninety
days after receipt of a completed application, unless one or more of the
following is found to be true, in which event the Borough shall deny the permit
within said ninety-day period:
      (1)   An applicant is under eighteen years of age;
      (2)   An applicant has failed to provide the information reasonably
necessary for issuance of the permit or has falsely answered a question or
request for information on the application form;
      (3)   The premises to be used for the adult entertainment establishment
does not meet each and every requirement of the ordinances of the Borough and
the laws of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania;
      (4)   The permit fee required by this chapter has not been paid;
      (5)   An applicant of the proposed establishment is in violation of, or
is not in compliance with, any of the provisions of this chapter.
   (c)   The permit, if granted, shall state on its face the name of the person
(s) or entity to whom it is granted, the name, address and telephone number of
the person in charge of the day to day affairs of the establishment, the
address of the adult entertainment establishment, and the issuance and
expiration date of said permit. The permit shall be posted in a conspicuous
space at or near the main public entrance to the adult entertainment
establishment so that it may be easily read at any time.
(Ord. 2235. Passed 8-10-98.)
806.07   FEES.
   The annual fee for an adult entertainment establishment shall be one
thousand, five hundred dollars ($1,500). This fee is intended to cover
substantially all costs, including an advertised public meeting with a
stenographic transcript, review by the Borough Solicitor and review by the
Lawrence County Planning Commission.
(Ord. 2235. Passed 8-10-98.)
806.08   INSPECTION.
   One who has been issued a permit shall, at any time that the adult
entertainment establishment is occupied or open for business, permit
representatives of the Ellwood City Borough Police Department, Ellwood City
Fire Department, Ellwood City Code Enforcement Office and the Lawrence County
Planning Commission to inspect the premises for the purposes of ensuring
compliance with the law.
(Ord. 2235. Passed 8-10-98.)
806.09   EXPIRATION OF PERMIT.
   (a)   Each permit shall expire one year from the date of issuance and may be
renewed only by complying with the application procedure set forth in this
chapter. Application shall be made at least ninety days before the permit
expiration date. A decision to renew or deny the issuance of a permit shall be
made within ninety days of receipt of the completed application by the Zoning
Office.
   (b)   Where the applicant certifies, under penalty of perjury, that no
change has occurred in the ownership, use, possession and/or physical structure
of the premises since the date of the issuance of the last permit, the
applicant shall be permitted to continue the operation of its business under
the exact provisions of said permit, pending a decision by the Zoning Office on
the renewal application.
(Ord. 2235. Passed 8-10-98.)
806.10   SUSPENSION AND REVOCATION OF PERMIT.
   (a)   The Zoning Office shall suspend a permit for a period not to exceed
thirty days if it is determined that a permittee or his or her employee or
agent has:
       (1)   Refused to allow an inspection of the adult entertainment
establishment as authorized by this chapter; or
      (2)   Violated the provisions of the laws of the Commonwealth of
Pennsylvania or the United States of America.
   (b)   The Zoning Office shall revoke a permit if a cause for suspension set
forth in subsection (a) hereof occurs and the permit has been suspended within
the preceding twelve months.
   (c)   The Zoning Office shall revoke a permit if it is determined that:
      (1)   A permittee gave false or misleading information in the material
submitted to the Borough during the application process;
      (2)   The permittee or his or her employee or agent has knowingly allowed
possession, use or sale of controlled substances on the premises;
      (3)   A permittee or his or her employee or agent has knowingly allowed
prostitution on the premises;
       (4)   A permittee or his or her employee or agent knowingly operated the
adult entertainment establishment during a period of time when the permittee's
permit was suspended;
      (5)   The permittee or his or her employee or agent has violated this
chapter, the laws of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania or the laws of the United
States of America, on three or more occasions.
(Ord. 2235. Passed 8-10-98.)
806.11   TRANSFER OF PERMIT.
   No permittee shall transfer a permit to any other person or entity or
operate an adult entertainment establishment under the authority of a permit at
any place other than the address designated in the application.
(Ord. 2235. Passed 8-10-98.)
806.99   PENALTY; EQUITABLE REMEDIES.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 of the Administration Code for general Code penalty if no specific
penalty is provided.)
   This chapter shall not be construed to limit the authority of the Borough to
pursue any and all other remedies and relief that may be available to it in law
or in equity under the laws applicable in any case.
(Ord. 2235. Passed 8-10-98.)
CHAPTER 812
Community Antenna Television Systems
812.01   License required.
812.02   License application; agreements; rules and regulations.
812.03   Nonexclusively of license; exception.
812.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Operation of cable television system by Borough - see Borough Code § 2471
(53 P.S. § 47471)
   Criminal mischief - see Crimes Code § 3304
   Theft of cable television services - see Crimes Code § 3926
   Discarding television sets and tubes - see Crimes Code § 6505
   Utility poles - see S.U. & P.S.
1050.08,
1050.11
812.01   LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall erect, install, maintain or operate a closed circuit
television transmission and distribution system within the limits of the
Borough of Ellwood City without first obtaining a license to do so, as granted
by Council.
(Ord. 1953. Passed 6-20-84.)
812.02   LICENSE APPLICATION; AGREEMENTS; RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   Any person, desiring to install, erect, operate or maintain a closed circuit
television transmission and distribution system in the Borough shall apply in
writing to Council for a license therefor. Council shall then consider a
licensing agreement with said applicant, shall pass upon said license
application and shall approve the same, provided that the agreement made with
the applicant provides reasonable rules, regulations and requirements regarding
the construction, operation and maintenance of the system and licensing fees
for the operation of the same. Council may, from time to time, amend the
licensing agreement when it finds that amendments to the licensing agreement
are necessary for the operation of the cable television system. Agreements and
subsequent amendments to any licensing agreement shall be accomplished by
resolution.
(Ord. 1953. Passed 6-20-84.)
812.03   NONEXCLUSIVELY OF LICENSE; EXCEPTION.
   Any license issued under this chapter shall be nonexclusive, except that
Council shall have the right to withhold the granting of more than one license
or any number of additional licenses if it decides that the needs of the
citizens of the Borough are adequately served by one licensee or a limited
number of licensees, and additional CATV operations would be detrimental to the
public interest.
(Ord. 1953. Passed 6-20-84.)
812.99   PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 of the Administration Code for general Code penalty if no specific
penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 820
Farmers Markets
820.01   License required; application; fee.
820.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Establishment and maintenance of markets by the Borough - see Borough Code §
1202(31) (53 P.S. § 46202(31))
   Power to license transient retail business - see Borough Code § 2901 (53
P.S. § 47901)
   Deceptive business practices - see Crimes Code § 4107
   Sunday sales - see Crimes Code § 7364
820.01   LICENSE REQUIRED; APPLICATION; FEE.
   Whoever wishes to offer for sale the produce of his or her farm, garden or
dairy during a period each year and at specific locations as may be designated
and established by Council, annually, shall first obtain a farmers market
license from the Secretary/Treasurer. The applicant for a license shall furnish
the Secretary/Treasurer with whatever information the Borough may request, and
shall agree to offer whatever items for sale at the location and the specific
area in that location that may be assigned to him or her at the farmers market
area. No license shall be issued until the applicant has paid to the Secretary/
Treasurer, for the use of the Borough, a license fee as established by
resolution of Council.
820.99   PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 of the Administration Code for general Code penalty if no specific
penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 824
Gasoline Storage Tanks and Pumps
824.01   Testing and inspection required.
824.02   Methods of testing and inspection.
824.03   Testing and inspection by owner; prior notice to Borough.
824.04   Authority of Fire Department to administer tests; costs.
824.05   Issuance of approval certificate.
824.06   Testing and inspection prior to start-up; notice to Borough.
824.07   Noncompliance; repairs and additions.
824.08   Prohibited operations.
824.09   Purpose; declaration of public nuisance.
824.10   Abandoned tanks.
824.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Authority to regulate quantities of dangerous and inflammable articles,
substances and materials - see Borough Code § 1202(23) (53 P.S. § 46202(23))
   Sale of gasoline in glass containers - see Crimes Code § 7305
   Fuel supply systems in flood hazard areas - see B. & H.
1482.22(m)
824.01   TESTING AND INSPECTION REQUIRED.
   Any person storing, measuring and/or dispensing at wholesale or retail any
gasoline or other motor fuel of a similar nature shall have tanks, pumps or
other measuring apparatus tested and inspected in the manner provided in this
chapter at least once every two years, unless more frequent testing and
inspection is required by the Fire Department.
(Ord. 1838. Passed 4-19-77.)
824.02   METHODS OF TESTING AND INSPECTION.
   The testing and inspection provided for in Section
824.01 shall be made by the owner of the tanks, pumps and other apparatus or
equipment provided for the storage and/or sale of gasoline or other motor
fuels, by a mercury or pressure gauge showing a pressure of five pounds
maintained for a period of thirty minutes.
(Ord. 1838. Passed 4-19-77.)
824.03   TESTING AND INSPECTION BY OWNER; PRIOR NOTICE TO BOROUGH.
   Testing and inspection shall be made by the owner of the tanks, pumps,
apparatus and equipment at his or her own expense and in the presence of an
authorized officer or agent of the Borough, the Borough having been given five
days prior notice of the time and place of such test and inspection.
(Ord. 1838. Passed 4-19-77.)
824.04   AUTHORITY OF FIRE DEPARTMENT TO ADMINISTER TESTS; COSTS.
   If the testing and inspection are made at the direction of the Fire
Department, the owner of the tanks, pumps, apparatus or equipment shall have
sixty days notice of the time and place of such test and inspection. At the
time the test is to be made, the owner shall provide the necessary gauge and
other equipment required to make the required tests. If the gauge and equipment
are not provided by the owner of the said tanks and pumps, the Borough may
provide such means of testing and the expense thereof shall be chargeable to
and collected from the owner of the tanks, pumps or other apparatus.
(Ord. 1838. Passed 4-19-77.)
824.05   ISSUANCE OF APPROVAL CERTIFICATE.
   When the tanks, pumps, apparatus and equipment have been duly tested as
required by this chapter and approved by the Fire Department, a certificate
shall be issued to the owner of the tanks, pumps and other apparatus or
equipment authorizing him or her to continue to store and/or sell at retail or
wholesale gasoline or motor fuel for a period of two years, unless a
reinspection and testing within that period of two years shall be required by
the Fire Department.
(Ord. 1838. Passed 4-19-77.)
824.06   TESTING AND INSPECTION PRIOR TO START-UP; NOTICE TO BOROUGH.
   Any person about to enter into the business of storing and/or selling
gasoline or other motor fuels at wholesale or retail within the Borough shall,
prior to beginning such business, have the tanks, pumps and equipment tested
and inspected as required by this chapter. Notice of the intention to begin the
business of storing and/or selling gasoline in the Borough shall be given to
the Fire Department in sufficient time to permit the testing and inspection
provided for in this chapter and to receive the required certificate from the
Borough authorizing the person to begin the operation of such business.
(Ord. 1838. Passed 4-19-77.)
824.07   NONCOMPLIANCE; REPAIRS AND ADDITIONS.
   Whenever the required testing and inspection of the tanks, pumps, apparatus
and equipment used in the storage and/or sale of gasoline and other motor fuels
in the Borough shows that the tanks, pumps, apparatus and equipment do not
comply with the provision of this chapter, such tanks, pumps, apparatus and
equipment shall not be used in any manner for the storage and sale of gasoline
until the proper additions and repairs have been made so that said equipment
can be used with safety to persons and property in the Borough. No certificate
shall be issued for the use of such tanks, pumps, apparatus and equipment until
the proper and necessary repairs and additions have been made.
(Ord. 1838. Passed 4-19-77.)
824.08   PROHIBITED OPERATIONS.
   No person shall operate any tank, pump, apparatus or equipment for the
storage and/or sale of gasoline or other motor fuels in the Borough otherwise
than as provided in this chapter.
(Ord. 1838. Passed 4-19-77.)
824.09   PURPOSE; DECLARATION OF PUBLIC NUISANCE.
   This chapter enacted for the purpose of providing reasonable and safe means
of storing and/or selling gasoline, which is a highly inflammable and dangerous
commodity. The maintenance of any storage or selling facility in the Borough in
violation of any provision of this chapter is hereby declared to be a public
nuisance and shall be abated as provided by law.
(Ord. 1838. Passed 4-19-77.)
824.10   ABANDONED TANKS.
   Tanks abandoned by property owners must be abandoned in accordance with the
law of the Commonwealth (Pennsylvania State Police Regulations for the
Procedure for Abandonment or Removal of Tanks, Article XV, passed 1971).
(Ord. 1838. Passed 4-19-77.)
824.99   PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 of the Administration Code for general Code penalty if no specific
penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 840
Mechanical and Electrical Amusement Devices
840.01   Mechanical or electrical amusement device defined.
840.02   Exemption of juke boxes.
840.03   Possession; license required.
840.04   Contents of license application.
840.05   Review of license application.
840.06   License fee.
840.07   Deductions and refunds.
840.08   Display of license; transfers.
840.09   Distributors' licenses.
840.10   Gambling devices.
840.11   Violations.
840.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Regulation and prohibition of amusements - see Borough Code § 1202(30) (53
P.S. § 46202(30))
   Gambling - see Crimes Code § 5512
   Slot machines; confiscation of gambling devices - see Crimes Code § 5513
   Sales of electronic, mechanical or other devices - see Crimes Code §§ 5705
et seq.
   Amusements generally - see Crimes Code §§ 7101 et seq.
840.01   MECHANICAL OR ELECTRICAL AMUSEMENT DEVICE DEFINED.
   As used in this chapter, “mechanical or electrical amusement device” means
any device, other than a juke box, which, upon insertion of a coin or disc, may
be operated for use as a game, entertainment or amusement, whether or not a
score is registered or a prize is whether or not a score is registered or a
prize is offered.
(Ord. 1934. Passed 5-6-82.)
840.02   EXEMPTION OF JUKE BOXES.
   The provisions of this chapter shall not be construed to apply to juke
boxes.
(Ord. 1934. Passed 5-6-82.)
840.03   POSSESSION; LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall, at any time, have in his or her possession within the
Borough any mechanical or electrical amusement device without first having
obtained a license therefor as provided in Sections
840.04 et seq.
(Ord. 1934. Passed 5-6-82.)
840.04   CONTENTS OF LICENSE APPLICATION.
   Any person who possesses a mechanical or electrical amusement device shall
make application for a license therefor with the Secretary/Treasurer, in
writing, setting forth:
   (a)   His or her present and previous occupations;
   (b)   The length and place of his or her present and previous residences;
   (c)   The name and address of the owner of the premises where the devices
are to be used;
   (d)   If the owner of the premises is not the applicant, the length of the
term of the lease of the premises;
   (e)   If the possessor is not the owner of the device, the name and address
of the owner of the said device;
   (f)   The location where the device is to be displayed or operated and the
business conducted at that place; and
   (g)   The type and serial number of the device sought to be licensed.
(Ord. 1934. Passed 5-6-82.)
840.05   REVIEW OF LICENSE APPLICATION.
   No license shall be granted until twenty-four hours after the application is
made to the Secretary/Treasurer, during which time the Police Chief and
Council's designee may investigate the facts set forth in the application.
(Ord. 1934. Passed 5-6-82.)
840.06   LICENSE FEE.
   The fee for the license required by Section
840.03 shall be established by Council. Such fee shall be payable upon
application for the license by the owner or operator of the establishment in
which the device is installed for use. If the license is renewed, the fee for
the same shall be due and payable on January 31 of each year.
(Ord. 1934. Passed 5-6-82.)
840.07   DEDUCTIONS AND REFUNDS.
   No deduction or refund of any license fee payable under Section
840.06 shall be granted in the event that any device is destroyed, stolen, sold
or otherwise disposed of, or transferred after the payment of the fee.
(Ord. 1934. Passed 5-6-82.)
840.08   DISPLAY OF LICENSE; TRANSFERS.
   (a)   The license required by Section
840.03 shall be posted permanently and conspicuously on the device.
   (b)   The license issued for any device may be transferred to another device
of similar nature in the same or a different location if, and only if,
application for the transfer is made in writing to the Secretary/Treasurer at
least three days prior to the date on which the transfer is to take place. Any
person who transfers a license from one device to another of similar nature, in
the same or a different location, without said notice, shall be guilty of a
summary offense.
(Ord. 1934. Passed 5-6-82.)
840.09   DISTRIBUTORS' LICENSES.
   Any person distributing a mechanical or electrical amusement device in the
Borough shall make application for a license with the Secretary/Treasurer,
setting forth the information required by Section
840.04. The fee for the distributor's license shall be established by
resolution of Council and shall be paid annually at the time of application.
(Ord. 1934. Passed 5-6-82; Ord. 1944. Passed 1-18-83.)
840.10   GAMBLING DEVICES.
   Nothing in this chapter shall in any way be construed to authorize, license
or permit any gambling device whatsoever, as defined by the Pennsylvania Crimes
Code.
(Ord. 1934. Passed 5-6-82.)
840.11   VIOLATIONS.
   No person shall violate of fail to comply with this chapter, neglect, fail
or refuse to furnish correct and complete reports or to pay the license fees
established pursuant to Section
840.06 or 840.09, at the time required, knowingly make any incomplete, false or
fraudulent report, or attempt to do anything whatever to avoid the payment of
the whole or any part of any license fee.
(Ord. 1934. Passed 5-6-82.)
840.99   PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 of the Administration Code for general Code penalty if no specific
penalty is provided.)
   In addition to the penalty provided in Section
202.99 of the Administration Code, the license of any person convicted of a
violation of any of the provisions of this chapter shall be revoked.
(Ord. 1934. Passed 5-6-82.)
CHAPTER 844
Newspaper Vending Machines
844.01   Findings; standards.
844.02   Sales of newspapers and local publications only.
844.03   Maintenance; adjacent sidewalks; obstructions.
844.04   Notification of location.
844.05   Attachment to utility poles or other equipment.
844.06   Protruding nails or hooks; additions.
844.07   Proximity to residences.
844.08   Display of owner's address and telephone number.
844.09   Removal for noncompliance.
844.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Placement of articles and merchandise on sidewalks - see GEN. OFF.
674.03
   Utility poles generally - see S.U. & P.S.
Ch. 1050
844.01   FINDINGS; STANDARDS.
   Newspaper vending machines used for the purpose of exhibiting for sale daily
newspapers and/or local weekly publications are permitted in the Borough of
Ellwood City. Council hereby finds that it is important for the safety of its
citizens, the use of their sidewalks and the protection of the aesthetic
qualities of residential neighborhoods that the following regulations be made,
setting standards for newspaper vending machines:
   (a)   No newspaper vending machine may be placed on a sidewalk having less
than a minimum width from the curb to the end of the sidewalk of four feet.
   (b)   All newspaper vending machines shall be placed or anchored onto a
cement base having the following dimensions:
         Depth (in.)         19.5
         Height (in.)         3.5
   (c)   Newspaper vending machines shall conform to the following dimensions:
         Width (in.)         19.5
         Depth (in.)         16.5
         Height (in.)         48.75
(Ord. 2150. Passed 6-20-94.)
844.02   SALES OF NEWSPAPERS AND LOCAL PUBLICATIONS ONLY.
   Nothing shall be exhibited, offered or sold from a newspaper vending machine
except daily newspapers and local weekly publications, and no person shall use
said newspaper vending machines for any purpose other than for the sale of such
newspapers and local weekly publications. Chairs, boxes and other articles
shall not be used in any manner while dispensing of newspapers from vending
machines. No vending machines, except those for which permits have been issued,
will be permitted on sidewalks.
(Ord. 2065. Passed 4-16-90.)
844.03   MAINTENANCE; ADJACENT SIDEWALKS; OBSTRUCTIONS.
   Newspaper vending machines shall be kept in a clean, orderly and sanitary
condition, and the portion of the sidewalk adjacent to the newspaper vending
machine shall be kept in a clean, orderly and sanitary condition. Such machines
shall be located so as not to interfere with the use of the street or sidewalk
by the public.
(Ord. 2065. Passed 4-16-90.)
844.04   NOTIFICATION OF LOCATION.
   No person shall place a newspaper vending machine on a public sidewalk
without first having notified the Borough, in writing, at the office of the
Manager, of the location of the newspaper vending machine.
(Ord. 2150. Passed 6-20-94.)
844.05   ATTACHMENT TO UTILITY POLES OR OTHER EQUIPMENT.
   No newspaper vending machine shall be attached to any utility pole,
luminary, light standard, light pole or other fixtures or equipment owned by
the Borough without the written consent of Council.
(Ord. 2150. Passed 6-20-94.)
844.06   PROTRUDING NAILS OR HOOKS; ADDITIONS.
   Newspaper vending machines must be free from nails, hooks or anything that
might protrude in such a way as to tear the clothing of or injure persons
passing on the sidewalk. Additions to newspaper vending machines will not be
permitted, except temporary tops and sides to be used in inclement weather,
which tops and sides may be made of wood, tin or metal.
(Ord. 2065. Passed 4-16-90.)
844.07   PROXIMITY TO RESIDENCES.
   No newspaper vending machine shall be placed within 150 feet of any
residence.
(Ord. 2150. Passed 6-20-94.)
844.08   DISPLAY OF OWNER'S ADDRESS AND TELEPHONE NUMBER.
   Any person placing or maintaining an outdoor newspaper vending machine on
any Borough sidewalk shall display in a place readily visible to the public, a
telephone number and address where the owner may be reached.
(Ord. 2065. Passed 4-16-90.)
844.09   REMOVAL FOR NONCOMPLIANCE.
   The appropriate officials of the Borough are hereby authorized, after ten
days written notice to any owner of a newspaper vending machine to correct any
use of the newspaper vending machine not in conformity with the standards of
this chapter, to remove the same and assess the cost of the removal to the
owner of said machine. Said machine shall be released only after the person has
paid the cost associated with its removal, including labor.
(Ord. 2150. Passed 6-20-94.)
844.99   PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 of the Administration Code for general Code penalty if no specific
penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 860
Transient Retail Businesses
860.01   Transient retail business defined.
860.02   License required; exemptions.
860.03   License application and issuance.
860.04   Custody and display of license.
860.05   Records; supervision of licensees.
860.06   Declaration of nuisance.
860.07   Suspension or revocation of license.
860.08   Violations.
860.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Power to license and regulate peddling - see Borough Code § 1202(31) (53
P.S. § 46202(31))
   Power to license transient retail businesses - see Borough Code § 2901 (53
P.S. § 47901)
   License fee exemptions - see Borough Code §§ 2901, 2904 et seq. (53 P.S. §§
47901, 47904 et seq.)
   Sale of obscene matter - see GEN. OFF.
678.04,
678.07
860.01   TRANSIENT RETAIL BUSINESS DEFINED.
   As used in this chapter, “transient retail business” means and includes the
following:
   (a)   Engaging in peddling, selling, canvassing, soliciting or taking
orders, either by sample or otherwise, for any goods, wares, merchandise or
services upon any street, alley, sidewalk or public place, or from house to
house, within the Borough; or
   (b)   Selling, soliciting or taking orders for any goods, wares or
merchandise from a fixed location within the Borough on a temporary basis,
which shall include, but shall not be limited to, any activities conducted at
the time of special occasions or celebrations, for seasonal purposes or in
advance of particular yearly holidays.
(1988 Code § 6-2061)
860.02   LICENSE REQUIRED; EXEMPTIONS.
   (a)   No person shall engage in any transient retail business within the
Borough without first having obtained from the Mayor a license and paying a fee
as established by resolution of Council.
   (b)   No license fee shall be required under this section:
      (1)   From farmers selling their own produce;
      (2)   For the sale of goods, wares and merchandise donated by the owner,
the proceeds of which are to be applied to any charitable or philanthropic
purpose; or
      (3)   From any manufacturer or producer in the sale of bread and bakery
products, meat and meat products or milk and milk products.
   (c)   A person dealing in one or more of the goods, wares or items of
merchandise not exempted pursuant to subsection (b) hereof shall be subject to
payment of the license fee fixed pursuant to this section for activities in
connection with the sale of goods, wares and merchandise not so exempted.
   (d)   No license fee shall be required from persons working without
compensation and selling goods, wares or merchandise for the sole benefit of
any nonprofit corporation or organization. However, the person in charge of
such nonprofit corporation or organization locally shall register with the
Mayor, giving pertinent information as requested by the Mayor, including the
names of persons to be engaged in the work and the length of time the
particular campaign shall be engaged in and the length of time the registration
should be in effect.
   (e)   A license issued under this section shall be issued on an individual
basis to persons engaging in a transient retail business. Every individual
shall obtain a separate license, issued to him or her in his or her name, and
the license fee imposed by this section shall be applicable to every individual
license.
(1988 Code § 6-2062)
860.03   LICENSE APPLICATION AND ISSUANCE.
   Any person desiring a license under this chapter shall first make
application for the license to the Mayor. If the person shall also be required
to obtain a license from any State or County officer, he or she shall, when
making the application, exhibit a valid license from the State or County
officer. The applicant shall give his or her name and address; the name of the
person by whom he or she is employed; the type of goods, wares and merchandise
he or she wishes to deal with in his or her transient retail business; the
number of persons to be employed by him or her in the Borough; and the types
and license numbers of all vehicles to be used, if any. The application shall
be accompanied by the license fee required by Section
860.02. The license shall be issued to the applicant following any
determination found by the Mayor to be necessary or desirable as to the
accuracy of the information on the application.
(1988 Code § 6-2063)
860.04   CUSTODY AND DISPLAY OF LICENSE.
   A license holder shall carry the license upon his or her person or display
it upon his or her vehicle, if he or she is engaged in a transient retail
business from house to house upon any street, alley, sidewalk or public ground
in the Borough, or display the license at the fixed location where he or she
shall engage in business, if doing so from a fixed location. The license holder
shall exhibit the license upon request to all police officers, Borough
officials and citizens or residents of the Borough.
(1988 Code § 6-2064)
860.05   RECORDS; SUPERVISION OF LICENSEES.
   The Mayor shall keep a record of all licenses issued under this chapter, and
the Mayor and the Chief of Police shall monitor the activities of all holders
of such licenses.
(1988 Code § 6-2066)
860.06   DECLARATION OF NUISANCE.
   The practice or custom of going in and upon private residences in the
Borough by solicitors, peddlers, itinerant merchants or transient retail
merchants, regardless of whether or not they hold a valid license under this
chapter, not having been requested or invited to do so by the owner or occupant
of such private residence, for the purpose of soliciting orders for the sale of
goods, wares or merchandise, or of disposing of or peddling or hawking goods,
wares or merchandise, is hereby declared to be a nuisance and a violation of
this chapter.
(1988 Code § 6-2067)
860.07   SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSE.
   The Mayor is hereby authorized to suspend or revoke any license issued under
this chapter when he or she deems the suspension or revocation to be in the
interest of the public health, safety or morals, or for a violation of any
provision of this chapter, or for giving false information upon the application
for a license under this chapter. Appeals from a suspension or revocation may
be made to Council at any time within ten days after such suspension or
revocation. No part of a license fee shall be refunded to any person whose
license has been suspended or revoked.
(1988 Code § 6-2068)
860.08   VIOLATIONS.
   No person, who is licensed under this chapter, shall do any of the
following:
   (a)   Sell any product or type of product not mentioned in the license;
   (b)   Hawk or cry his or her wares upon any street, alley, sidewalk or
public ground in the Borough, or use any loudspeaker or horn or other device
for announcing his or her presence, by which the public may be annoyed;
   (c)   When selling from a vehicle, stop or park the vehicle upon any street
or alley in the Borough for longer than necessary in order to sell from the
vehicle to persons residing or working in the immediate vicinity; or
   (d)   Engage in any house-to-house activity, except by prior appointment, at
any time on Sunday, or on any other day of the week before 9:00 a.m. or after
5:00 p.m.
(1988 Code § 6-2065)
860.99   PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 of the Administration Code for general Code penalty if no specific
penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 862
Transient Shows
862.01   Transient show defined.
862.02   Permit required; application; fee.
862.03   Investigations; conditions of permit.
862.04   Waiver or refund of fee.
862.05   Revocation of permit.
862.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Power to license and regulate amusements - see Borough Code § 1202(30) (53
P.S. § 46202(30))
   Theft of services - see Crimes Code § 3926
   Disorderly conduct - see Crimes Code § 5503
   Exhibitions of obscene and other sexual materials and performances - see
Crimes Code § 5903
   Public exhibition of insane or deformed persons - see Crimes Code § 5904
   Amusements generally - see Crimes Code §§ 7101 et seq.
   Obstructions and special uses of public ways - see TRAF.
Ch. 440
862.01   TRANSIENT SHOW DEFINED.
   As used in this chapter, the term “transient show” means any circus,
carnival or other show, entertainment or exhibition to which the public or any
part thereof is admitted, for which an admission fee is charged or for which
money or any other nature of regard is in any manner demanded or received, and
which shall be conducted or held at any place in the Borough other than on a
regular daily or weekly schedule throughout the year or major portion thereof.
Nothing herein shall apply to any lecture on current events or on any
scientific, historical, religious or literary subject, to any musical concert,
to any exhibition of statuary, painting or handicraft or to any church or
school affair.
(Ord. 1301. Passed 12-12-56.)
862.02   PERMIT REQUIRED; APPLICATION; FEE.
   No person shall hold or conduct any transient show without having first
obtained a permit therefor and having conformed to all provisions of this
chapter. Any person desiring such a permit shall make application to the Mayor
at least ten days before the date on which such person proposes to hold the
first performance of the show, and shall indicate on the application the nature
of the show, and shall indicate on the application the nature of the show, the
person conducting the show, the place where the show is proposed to be held and
any other information that the Mayor or Council may require. A fee as
established by resolution of Council shall be payable, for the use of the
Borough, to the Mayor, upon issuance of the permit.
(Ord. 1301. Passed 12-12-56.)
862.03   INVESTIGATIONS; CONDITIONS OF PERMIT.
   Prior to the issuance of a permit, the Mayor shall investigate or cause to
be investigated the character of the show for which the permit is requested,
the place at which the show is proposed to be held and the organization or
purpose that the show purposes to benefit, if the applicant claims that the
show is to be held for a charitable or benevolent purpose. The Mayor may refuse
to issue a permit for any show if, in his or her judgment, its character is
unlawful, obscene, indecent or injurious to the morals of the public, or if the
place where the show is proposed to be held is for any reason unsafe for the
purpose, considering the character of the place and of the show and the number
of persons likely to attend. Investigation by the Mayor shall be concluded
within one week following the filing of the application for the permit. The
Mayor may grant a permit subject to conditions relating to the character of the
show, adherence by the holder of the permit to protective and fire prevention
measures and limitation of the number of persons in attendance at any one time.
Any refusal of a permit by the Mayor shall be subject to review and
reconsideration by Council upon appeal by the applicant.
(Ord. 1301. Passed 12-12-56.)
862.04   WAIVER OR REFUND OF FEE.
   Council may waive payment of the permit fee or direct the refund of a fee
already paid in the case of any show held for any charitable or benevolent
purpose.
(Ord. 1301. Passed 12-12-56.)
862.05   REVOCATION OF PERMIT.
   The Mayor shall have authority to revoke a permit issued under Sections
852.02 and 852.03 if conditions of the permit are not adhered to or the show is
found to be not in conformity with the information given in the application for
the permit. In case of revocation of any such permit, no refund of any fee paid
for the permit shall be made.
(Ord. 1301. Passed 12-12-56.)
862.99   PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 of the Administration Code for general Code penalty if no specific
penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 864
Public Assemblies, Parades and Block Parties
864.01   Definitions.
864.02   Permit required.
864.03   Exceptions.
